div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of “Othello'' and of Ford's “Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: THE KHEDIVE AND THE “TIMES.”
div.p: The following are the criticisms of the “ Times ” on the recent declarations of the Khedive :—.

— There was a time, only a few years ago, when such an interview as that which the Khedive has granted to a French journalist, and our Paris Correspondent reports to-day, would have given occasion for grave uneasiness. That we can now afford to regard it as nothing more than an unpleasant reminder of the Khedive’s usual attitude towards this country is a sign of the increased strength of our position in Egypt, and still more of our cordial relations with the other Power chiefly interested in Northern Africa. The whole character of the Khedive’s remarks invites this reflection, though it shows only too plainly that the change is none of his seeking. But even if the tone of the interview did not suggest this contrast between the present and the past, His Highness has added a curious remark at the end which would make it impossible for us to forget the fact. He gave his interlocutor, the special correspondent of the “Temps,” a greeting to the French people with these enigmatic words:—“ We do not forget what they have been for us, and we are very fond of them “ all the same. ” It is the French journalist who italicized the words which our Paris Correspondent has reported. If they mean anything, there is only one meaning they can bear. The Khedive dates the strain which France has put upon his friendship from her conclusion of the entente with us. Provisions about Egypt, like provisions about Morocco, formed an integral part of the agreement, and it is as a result of them, and of their loyal observance by France, that we have been able to carry on our salutary work in Egypt with no fear of vexatious obstruction. To any one who protests his devotion to his country’s welfare so strongly as the Khedive this ought to be a matter for genuine satisfaction. But it is evidently to the period before the entente that His Highness’s pleasant recollections are confined—a period when French interests were inconstant antagonism to our own, and when the progress and security of Egypt were exposed to continual risk on account of this friction. We do not suppose for a moment that the French people will take the Khedive's view of recent history. If they continue in friendly intercourse with Egypt, we shall be as gratified as His Highness, but we do not think they will show a disposition to return to the attitude that preceded the entente. The mutual benefits of the entente, moral and material, are too well realized, the solidarity of our interests in Northern Africa is too plain, for either nation to be willing to disturb it at the prompting of an interested third party.

The substance of the Khedive’s remarks is, we are sorry to say, in only too faithful agreement with his final innuendo. No one ignorant of the modern history of Egypt, and going to this conversation for enlightenment, would guess even remotely what its course had been. He would imagine the Egyptians to be a people who had worked out their own salvation. He would suppose this to have been done under the beneficent initiative of Abbas II.—a much-suffering ruler who, however, even in the darkest moments never relaxed his ungrudging efforts for his people’s good. That the country had been brought out of distracted anarchy by the tutelage of another Power ; that this Power had preserved both the dynasty and the safety of its heritage — all this would never dawn on one who took his history from the Khedive. Yet the father of Abbas II. owed his retention of the throne to us. His Highness himself owes his personal security and the integrity of his dominions to the support of British power. The material develo­ment of his country, on which he dwells with complacency, is due similarly to Great Britain ; for, as a French writer pointed out in the Depeche Coloniale the other day, it was she who inspired capital with confidence and attracted it to Egypt, by consolidating the political situation, establishing order in the administration and finances, and undertaking the great public works in aid of commerce and agriculture. At one or two points of the interview, it is true, the Khedive tries to reassure opinion. He declares emphatically that it is wrong to assume that the “national” claims are anti-foreign and fanatic. We would gladly accept that assurance, but we cannot forget that it is precisely the same as those lavished by the notorious agitator Mustapha Pasha Kamel, whose national patriotism is of an unmistakably anti-British brand. Though His Highness deprecates the idea that he could possibly become a despot, it would not be too much to say that, in the necessarily restricted sphere where he now wields personal authority, it bears every mark of arbitrariness. Nor can a single-minded devotion to progress be seriously claimed by a ruler who has stood aside, often ostentatiously, from our efforts to benefit Egypt, and who allows favouritism and corruption to be rife in the public departments which still come within his influence.
The "Times" concludes with the following comments on the letter of Sir Christopher Furness, of which a telegraphic summary has appeared in a former issue.

A truer picture of the real Egypt, and of the men who have made it, is to be gathered from the instructive letter by Sir Christopher Furness M. P, He has returned from a stay in Egypt, “ where the extraordinary results of British administrative genius, ’ as he says, “ compel admiration.” But having enough experience of men and cities to know that a short tour in another land does not qualify the visitor to say the last word about it, he tells us that he would not have raised his protest against the policy pursued by a fellow Liberal, Mr. J. M. Robertson, M.P., if he did not know that Mr. Robertson’s acquaintance with Egypt were no greater than his own. But Mr. Robertson, and other Englishmen who like traducing the work of their country abroad, never allow the scantiness of their knowledge to stop them. Where their aspersions come into touch with facts they can generally be refuted without much trouble, as Sir Christopher Furness refutes them in a single particular by his effective account of the reform of justice under Lord Cromer’s administration. Nor do the traducers carry enough weight at home for sensible people to pay much attention to them. But it is otherwise among the native populations with whom they are constantly making mischief, and to the credulous, excitable Egyptian public it may seem a matter of real significance that letters by Mr. Robertson, a British member of Parliament and one of the Government’s supporters, should appear in the Cairo “Standard,” Mustapha Kamel’s Nationalist organ. As regards British policy it is of no significance, unless it be significant that, after the severe handling he received from Sir Edward Grey last summer, Mr. Robertson should have thought it safer to transfer his reflections from the House of Commons to a Cairene journal. But native readers do not appreciate this, and all the heavier, therefore, is the responsibility of those Europeans who seek to play on their ignorance and fanaticism. Influences of this kind, whether consciously or unconsciously exerted, are not confined to Egypt. The French, who are now deploring the brutal assasination of a fellow-countryman in Morocco, are inclined to read in this regrettable event another sign of the mischievous effect which political intrigues in Europe have had on the receptive Moorish mind.

Luxor Winter Palace
In consequence of the Luxor Winter Palace being still half full, the management have decided not to close it until the 15th inst.
H.M.S. Minerva.
H.M.S Minerva is due at Port Said from Malta to-day and it is expected that she will make a stay of some six months in Egyptian waters.
Death Sentence.
The execution of Abd el Mewla Mohamed, found guilty of wilful murder, will take place at Alexandria prison at ten o’clock to-morrow morning.
Rabies In Alexandria,

The Alexandria Municipality have given notice that in consequence of cases of rabies having recently occurred, mainly at Ramleh, all dogs must not only carry their registration number but must also either be muzzled or led on a leash.
Salaries of Tribunal Officials.

The commission appointed by the Ministry of Justice to study the question of raising the salaries of the staff of the Native Tribunals and Mehkemehs Sharieh, has concluded its work, and will submit its report shortly to the Ministry of Finance.
The Mosque Students.

The grand sheikh of the Ulemas at Alexandria is undertaking the provision of respectable lodgings for the poorer students of the mosques of Alexandria, and each of these will be supplied with a free bed. Two Alexandrian notables have subscribed forty beds.
Mr. Moore Acquitted.

The official inquiry into the Ministry of Public Works scandal has now been closed. Mr. Moore was discharged from the suspicion of corruption imputed to him, but Ahmed Effendi El-Sarfani and another official of that ministry were found guilty. They were therefore arrested and will be brought shortly before the court for trial.
Wakfs Supreme Council.

The Supreme Council of Wakfs which met yesterday in Cairo, under the presidency of Adli Pasha Yaghen, has decided to grant the Mohamed Aly and the Damanhour Industrial Schools L.E. 1,000 and LE. 500, respectively, as annual graints-in-aid. The Council has also decided to appoint a native physician to accompany pilgrims to Mecca in future.
Train de Luxe Collision.

We are officially informed that early yesterday morning the train de luxe running from Luxor to Cairo was wrongly admitted into a siding at Manfeloot station and collided with a goods train standing in the siding. None of the passengers were hurt, but the brakesman of the train de luxe sustained slight injury. The traffic was considerably delayed by the accident.
Egypt's Trade

Prof Arminjon, who recently issued a book on the Mohammedan Universities of Cairo, has now published (through the house of Larose of Paris, in the transactions of a publication society which bears the name of M Sirey Le commerce extérieur de l'Egypte. It is to be commended to all who are interested in trade statistics. The newest point in the thin volume is the proof given that the construction of the Suez Canal was fatal to a large Egyptian transport, entrepôt, and re-exportation business.
The Russian Concert

The concert given yesterday afternoon at the New Khedivial Hotel, Alexandria, by the celebrated Russian artists, Miss Vera and Miss Nadesda Chernetzka, was a great success, and all those who were fortunate enough to be present were delighted with the magnificent execution and technique of these Russian ladies. The programme included some of the choicest works of modern composers. Miss Nadesda Cberuetzka is a splendid contralto and her renderings from Glinka’s “La Vie pour le Czar,” Saint Saëns’ ‘Samson et Delila,” the “Habauera” in “Carmen,” and “Les Cloches” of Taskin were enthusiastically applauded. Miss Vera Chernetzka’s, the pianist, execution of Back’s Orgue Toccata et Fugue D. Moll (Tansig) and Tschakowski’s paraphrase were especially noteworthy. These ladies will give a second concert at the New Khedivial Hotel,.on Thursday next at 9.30 p.m.

div.head: LORD CROMER. SITUATION IN EGYPT. IMPORTANT INTERVIEW.
div.p: The account of an important interview with Lord Cromer appears in the “Temps.” The interview was granted to M. René Puaux and took place recently at Cairo. His Lordship expressed the great satisfaction which he felt at the recent revival of French interest in Egypt. He always had the interests of the Anglo-French “entente cordiale” at heart and the agreement between the two countries was felt in Egypt as making for the policy of progress which he is pursuing.

Lord Cromer then went on to speak of his report on Egypt for 1906. He declared that he again treats of the subject of the Capitulations in this report but does not deal with them with a view to their suppression but with the object of adapting them to the modern conditions prevailing in Egypt by transferring their legal functions to Great Britain.

Lord Cromer made some important observations on one of the developments of the extraordinary financial and commercial prosperity of Egypt, and expressed some anxiety about the great increase in the numbers of the new companies, which had been floated of late on the local market. M René Puaux in commenting on their animadversions of his Lordship added that the slightly pessimistic tone in Lord Cromer’s allusions to this subject were easily comprehensible as coming from a man of such proverbial integrity, as was acknowledged even by his adversaries, and were inspired by a dislike of the profits not produced by work.

div.head: THE DUKE OF CONNAUGHT.
div.p: At eleven o’clock yesterday morning H.R.H the Duke of Connaught paid a visit to H.H. the Khedive at Abdin Palace, and shortly after midday the Khedive returned the Duke’s visit at the British Agency.
In the afternoon His Royal Highness, accompanied by Major-General Sir John Maxwell, and Mr. Myles Ponsonby, visited Count von Moers at the Semiramis Hotel.

div.head: EGYPTIAN ARMY.
div.p: We understand that El-Miralai Asser Bey will be promoted to the rank of Lewa and appointed Adjutant General of the Egyptian Army. The appointment of such a capable and popular officer to this high post will, we are sure, be received with great satisfaction throughout all the Army.
We sincerely congratulate El-Lewa Asser Pasha upon his well deserved promotion.
The following transfers and appointments have been approved :—
El Miralai J. J. Asser Bey, Station Commandant, Khartoum to be Adjutant General.
El Kaimakam W. H. Drake Bey, Deputy Assistant Adjutant General, to be Assistant Adjutant General.

div.head: EGYPTIAN NATIONALISM. THE KHEDIVE’S DECLARATIONS.
div.p: The declarations of the Khedive to M. Puaux are the subject of considerable comment in the local Press and it is assumed that the statements made by His Highneea on the subject of the national claims show that he has taken his position in the Egyptian Nationalist Party. The frankness, with which the Khedive specially alluded to the national claims should not be received with any uneasiness for it has long been known how much His Highness sympathised with that section of the natives, who are designated by the vague term “The Nationalist Party.” On the contrary the fact that his Highness has emerged from his obscurity and publicly allowed his political ideals to be proclaimed to the world should do much to make the situation in Egypt clearer, especially in England.

La “Reforme” lays special stress on the Khedive’s statements on the subject of “révendications nationales” and remarks “To-day the Khedive declares himself as the guarantor before the world of the sentiments of his subjects, and he defines the character of the national claims. It is in this phrase that all the importance of the interview granted to the distinguished representative of the “Temps” lies.”

The “Progres” states that the remarks of the Khedive show that his Highness has taken his place in the ranks of the Nationalist Party. “None of the ‘national claims’ made by the “Lewa” and repeated by the National Assembly have been forgotten by the Khedive. The satisfaction of the intellectual and moral needs of the people, the co-operation of the nation with the Sovereign, all such statements form a fitting pendant in the interview with his denial, as to the existence of fanaticism, and his silence in regard to the Occupation. However, the declarations of the Khedive have one merit, namely in the fact that they have rendered all equivocation impossible. The Khedive declared that he never disdained advice. But this announcement is historically incorrect. However, if it shows a new disposition on the part of the Khedive the announcement is most opportune, for the Khedive never needed good advice more than he does now. The best advice to give him is to recall to his mind the history of the Princes, who are his immediate predecessors. He will see that the Khedive Ismail lost his throne because he fraternised with the National Party and that the Khedive Tewfik owed his throne to the Occupation, which crushed that party. The connection of the Khediviate with the National Party has always been fatal.”

“Al Moayad” remarks: We have conned his Highness's declarations over and over again and cannot find a single word which his Highness should have left unsaid. As a native of high rank, as the ruler of Egypt, and as a Moslem Emir, who knows his religion and the circumstances of other religions in the East and West, the Khedive had the right to say every word of the declaration in question.

“Al Gerida” remarks :— “What in the Khedive’s declarations can have offended the British? Is it because he did not give high praise to the Government ? The last sentences of his Highness’s statements (“I have never opposed measures which I thought to be useful to Egypt I have never disdained advice.”) can only mean that the prosperity of the country, to which he referred, was the fruit of the works of the Government, and necessarily through the advice of the occupants.”

“Al Minbar” says:– “As we have already said the statements of the Khedive are simple and contain nothing extraordinary. Those who endeavour to associate his Highness with any political party are only the dukhala enemies of Egypt and the Egyptians, and also of the British. On reading the “Times” comments we could find nothing worthy of translation. Weakness and perplexity are evident in that paper's article”.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA FLOWER SHOW.
div.p: H.H. the Khedive has consented to open the Alexandria Horticultural Flower Show at San Stefano on the 20th inst. at 3 p.m.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Khedivial mail steamship Assouan will leave Alexandria at 4 p.m. on Saturday and Port-Said at 4 p.m. on Sunday for Jaffa, Caiffa, Beyrouth, Tripoli, Mersina, and Alexandretta.
The Moss liner Menepthah arrived yesterday noon from Liverpool via Gibraltar, Algiers and Malta, with passengers, mails and general cargo.

div.head: OBITUARY.
MR. E. C. HOGG.
div.p: We regret to announce the death of Mr. E. C. Hogg, which took place this morning at his Cairo residence at Ghezireh. He was recently attacked by pneumonia and his fragile constitution was incapable of resisting the malady. The death of Mr. Hogg will cause great regret at Cairo and Alexandria for he counted a large circle of friends in both cities. He wasabn old resident at Alexandria and had lived here for many years during his official career in the Coastguards Administration, which he joined from the Royal Navy. A few years ago be retired from the service and embarked as a stockbroker in Cairo, where he had considerable success and was trusted by a large number of clients who had an unfailing confidence in the sterling integrity of his character and the keenness of his judgment in financial matters.
He leaves a widow, the daughter of Mr. Peel of Alexandria, and a young family to deplore his loss.

div.head: THE IRISH DINNER.
div.p: The Irish dinner was held last night at the Grand Continental Hotel under the presidency of Mr. J. Langley. The dinner was largely attended, over fifty members of the Irish colony in Cairo being present. After the toast of the King had been honoured, Mr. Langley, in giving the toast of Ireland, expressed his deep regret at the sad event which had led to the postponement of the dinner. By the death of Mr. Verschoyle he had lost a dear friend and colleague.

The chairman then described the progress of the Irish dinner club, pointing out that it had trebled its number of members since the first dinner was given four years ago. He was glad to see so many members of the two famous Irish regiments, the Inniskilling Dragoons and the Inniskilling Fusiliers, who, he hoped would long remain in Cairo.
He then called upon every Irishman present to drink the toast of Ireland. No further speeches were made, and the rest of the evening passed quietly, an informal smoking concerned being organised.

Great credit is due to the secretary, Mr. L. B. Weldon, who spared no effort in organising the dinner, and we must not forget the band of the Inniskilling Fusiliers, who gave a fine selection of Irish airs.

div.head: H DE VRIES ET BOUTIGNY, LTD.,
div.p: This concern was registered at Somerset House on March 25, by Farrar, Porter and Co, 2, Wardrobe Place, Doctor’s Commons, E.C Capital, £300,000, in 297,500 Ordinary shares of £1 each and 50,000 Founder’s shares of Is each. Objects: To acquire, develop and extend the business carried on at Cairo as H. de Vries and Boutigny ; to adopt an agreement with the said firm, H.H. de Vries and H. Boutigny; and to carry on in the United Kingdom, Egypt and elsewhere, the business of stock and share dealers, brokers and jobbers, bankers, bullion merchants, financiers, cotton and produce dealers and brokers, dealers in land and real estate, concessionnaires, merchants, guarantors, etc. The signatories are:—

cell.p: H.H, deVries and H. Boutigny, both of Cairo, stock brokers and bankers
E.F. Mills, 48, Arodene Road, Brixton Hill, S.W., rate collector
S.W. Harrell, 269, Coldharbour Lane, Brixton, S.W., law clerk
F W. Godwin, 481, Hanover Buildings, Tooley Street, S.E., law clerk
C.J. Baker, 43, Lyndhurst Avenue, Streatham Hill, S. W., law clerk
L. Stephen, 2, Wardrobe Place, Doctors’ Commons, E. C., solicitor

row.cell: G.J. Bayspool Porter, 2, Wardrobe Place, Doctors’ Commons, E.C., solicitor

div.p: Minimum cash subscription, 25 per cent, of the shares offered to the public. The first directors (to number not less than two nor more than nine) are: H.H. de Vries, H. Boutigny, E.F. Mills, S.W. Harrell, F.W. Godwin, C.J. Baker, L. Stephen, J.G Relin and G.J. Bayspool Porter. Qualification (except signatories while acting as provisional directors,) £10. Remuneration, £200 each per annum and a share in the profits as undermentioned ; 5 per cent. of any available profits is to be carried to reserve until such reserve reaches 10 per cent. of the paid-up capital, and afterwards 2½ per cent. of such profits (with a maximum of £10,000 in any year) is to be paid to each of the first managing directors as additional remuneration. The balance is to be applied first in payment of a cumulative preferential dividend of 5 per cent on the Ordinary shares. Of any surplus still remaining, 5 per cent. is to be paid to the directors as additional remuneration (with a maximum of £15,000 in any one year), 50 per cent. is to be applied as further dividend on the Ordinary shares or carried to reserve, or otherwise dealt with as the company in general meeting may determine, and 45 per cent is to be divided amongst the holders of the Founders' shares.

div.head: END OF THE SEASON. LAST SAVOY DANCE.
div.p: Though no dance was advertised for Saturday night at the Savoy, but rumours had gone abroad that the ballroom and orchestra would be available should they be wanted ; and as many people turned up for dinner and several big parties had been arranged, the evening terminated with quite one of the cheeriest dances of the season. Mrs. Berners was one of those who entertained quite a large party of friends, her guests including Lady Rogers, the Hon. C. Littleton, Capt. and Mrs. Rome, Miss Leverieh, Miss Hurley, Capt. and Mrs. Schreiber, Miss A. Reed, Miss Schreiber, Miss Yorke, Capt. Pardou, Mr. L Reid, Mr. F. Watson, Mr. Barton, Mr. K. Speir, and Mr. Barnard. Sir James also had a party, among whom were Mr. and Mrs. Appleton, Miss Fulpin, Miss Blyth, Col. Maberly, Col. Persse, Major Neil Haig, Capt. Mattheuws, Capt. Darrell, and Mr. Parker. Lord and Lady Carnarvon were entertaining Lord and Lady Lanesborough among their other guests. Mr. and Mrs. Smallman had a party of twelve, and Capt. and Mrs. Fitzgerald had guests with them, as had also Mr. and Mrs Peach. Mr. Horschitz was entertaining Mr. and Miss Bennett and Miss Ers ine Shaw ; and many of the officers of the various regiments were also dining in the restaurant. Quite a number of other residents arrived after dinner, and the dance, which was supposed to be quite an informal affair sans programmes, sans buffet, developed into one of the usual order, light refreshments being provided, and many suppers being ordered afterwards. Though there were plenty of dancers there was no crowd, and altogether this impromptu affair proved most successful.

We hear that there are to be no more dances this season at the Semiramis Hotel ; and it is probable that the one at Mena House this week will be the last of the series. Those on Monday night at Shepheard’s may be continued for some weeks yet, but it is not likely that there will be any more at Ghezireh after this week.

div.head: STRIKE OF COAL HEAVERS
div.p: Our Port Said correspondent writes :—The coal discharging Arabs at this port have gone on strike, their demand being an increase in pay of 25 cts. per ton discharged. Some eight or nine colliers are in the harbour waiting to discharge, and the coal supply in the lighters is rapidly becoming exhausted. It is feared that influence is being brought to bear upon the coal-loading Arabs in order to make the strike general and that serious results may ensue.
Port Said, Tuesday.
The bunkering Arabs have joined the strike and the ships are compelled to coal with their own crews.

div.head: EASTER DAY AT ST. MARKS.
div.p: The Easter Festival celebrated on Sunday last was encouraging from every point of view. At the first service, 7 a.m, there were 19 communicants, at the 8 o’clook service 80, and at the midday service 72, a total of 171 compared with 141 in the previous year This must be greatly appreciated by Canon Ward, the Chaplain. The musical part of the services was excellently rendered and showed the care the choir had taken in rehearsing the music. The morning service opened with Hymn 134 sung to the well known “Ancient and Modern” tune, but whose author is unknown. The “Te Deum” by Vine Hall and the Choral Communion Service by Baptiste Calkin were carefully given and with good precision. We hope the choir will repeat these. The anthem in the morning was Myles Foster’s “As it began to dawn towards the first day of the week, ” which concludes with Bishop Wordsworth’s Hymn “ Allelulia ! Alleiulia ! Hearts and voices heavenward raise, ” set to beautiful music by Foster. The solos were taken by Miss Maud Callender and Mr. Percy Smith, both being in excellent voice and singing well. The choir also acquitted themselves well. At the close of the morning service the National Anthem was sung. The Anthem “As it began to dawn” was repeated in the evening, when Vine Hall’s “Magnificat” and “Nunc Dimittis” were beautifully given and reflected credit on the careful handling by the choir. The organist, Mr. Heaton gave valuable assistance throughout the day and at the close of each service gave Gaul’s “Soldiers' March,” from the Holy City.” Special mention is due to the willing helpers, who so tastefully and appropriately decorated the Church. Miss Dodd was responsible for the pulpit; Miss Morrison and Miss Barwell for the font; Mrs Eyre and Miss Spurgeon for the lectern; Mrs. and Miss Roberts for the choir stalls : Miss Batcheller for the chapel; Mrs Algernon Ward for the altar gases. Among those who sent plants and flowers were Mmes. Borton, Crafton, Dickson, Foster, Hopkinson, Picton, Preston, W. T Smith, and Messrs. Batcheller, Coates, Morrison, and Messrs. Cornish and Ebell.
The offertory for the poor at the early services amounted to P T. 600 in addition to the Easter offering of P.T. 5,623 whioh was presented as usual to the assistant chaplain.

div.head: NEW KHEDIVIAL HOTEL CAIRO.
div.p: Family Hotel. Built in 1904. Between Shepheard's Hotel and the Railway Station. Electric Light. Lift.
Sanitary arrangements up to-date. Open all the year round. Special terms for Government officials and Army of Occupation
NEW MANAGEMENT. 29242-26-11-90

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: H.R.H. Landgraf of Hess passed through Port Said to-day on the P. & O. mail boat Marmora, bound from Colombo to London via Marseilles. His Highness entertained a party of friends at the Eastern Exchange.
The Sirdar is expected to arrive at Khartoum to-day or to-morow.
Leave of absence from the 8th inst. to July has been granted to Major E Fetherstonhaugh, with permission to travel in Turkey, and to Captain D. Mathers.
Lieutenant J H. J. Phillips, 3rd Battalion Coldstream Guards, and Mrs. Phillips will embark for England on the Orotava on the 8th inst.

Sir Thomas Henry Elliot, K.C.B., whose death is reported by a Reuter's telegram, was born in London on September 7, 1854, and was the eldest son of the late Thomas Henry Elliot of Rue Ruhmkorff, Paris. He was educated privately and at the age of eighteen he entered the Inland Revenue Department by open competition. He was private Secretary to the Rt. Hon. C.T. Ritchie, when the latter was president of the Local Government Board, and for six years he was member of the Royal Commission on Local Taxation. Since 1892 he had been Secretary to the Board of Agriculture and Fisheries. He was created C B. in 1897 and and in 1902 was made K. C. B. He married a daughter of the late Jamas Rowe in 1880.

div.head: M. PUAUX IN EGYPT.
div.p: M. George Vayssié continues his career as a humorist of a high order. Saturday’s “Journal du Cairo” contains a really brilliant parody of M. Puaux’s letters to the “Temps” from which we take the following passage.

“The famous Paris journal “La Nuit” has just despatched to Egypt the equally famous reporter Dupont, the well known globe-trotter who discovered Naples and Vesuvius in 1906. We have been lucky enough to have communicated to us the eminent M. Dupont’s first letter to “La Nuit” This is rare good fortune. We even give our readers the first view, for the article will be published in “La Nuit” before they appear in Paris.

“Notes by the way. At Sea. The sea is really a very curious thing. I don’t really know why so much merriment has been expended on Marshal MacMahon. In the presence of the ocean he ejaculated “What a lot of water" and yet that is the cry that rises to one's lips in face of the boundless horizon........................ There is even too much of it, for excess is a defect. Shipwrecks in fact can only be attributed to a super-abundanoe of water ! The victims of the deep nearly always perish through submersion. Cases like the “Iena” disaster are decidedly rare. There is too much water below and around them. If there were less water below it the ship could ride out the storm resting on the bottom—if these were less all around the shipwrecked could easily gain dry land................. ...

In sight of the shore of Africa. I have just experienced a strong emotion. A sort of illuminated tower rises over there from the sea. I ask what it is. They reply “c’est Le Phare d’Alexandrie.” Antiquities exercise a real fascination upon me. There is the celebrated monument which since Alexander’s days has thrown its beams over the waters...
At Alexandria. Must confess my self quite astonished by my arrival at Alexandria.

Quite a European town. Good quays, docks and even carriages. Th-employes are decently dressed and appear to be able to write. In the streets few or none are completely naked. At the hotel my astonishment redoubles......On a table I find a copy of “La Nuit” Who would have believed it! They read “La Nuit” at Alexandria! And here are the “Figaro,” “La Vie Parisienne.” Some traveller must have left them here.….

The Great Interview. By the exercise of great skill I have at last obtained an interview with H H. the Khedive. I arranged the scheme of my questions with address, and thanks to my methods, the character and intentions of the Sovereign appear under a blinding light...I asked H. H. the Khedive, Abbas Hilmi the following questions.
“ Is it true your Highness that you have prepared a coup d’etat against England for the night of March 31—April 1 next.

“ This report is quite unfounded—I have prepared no such coup, for the excellent reason that I cannot. I should obviously be delighted to show Lord Cromer to the door, but as there is a chance of reciprocity being practised in these matters I prefer to abstain.”
“ Is it true that your Highness is a fanatic and loathes Europeans. ?

“ Not a shade of fanaticism is in me. As a Moslem I naturally set the Moslems above all other peoples, and their religion above all other religions which are utter impostures. Were I an absolute monarch I should obviously deprive myself of the assistance of European gentleman, if not of European ladies, for I know how to make destructions between Europeans well enough. But I am not an absolute monarch.
“ Is it a fact, that your Highness is wasting your civil list and personal, fortune in rash extravagance. ”

“ That is not strictly true. I myself indulge in strict economy, for a Sovereign should set the example of thrift, parsimony and good bargains to his people. Some princes of my family do not seem to look at things in the same light, so I have been obliged to retain in my possession a part of their allowances, of which they made the most deplorable use. Morality ! that is my motto.
(To be Continued. – Sometime).
